commit_message:
Handle a failure on communicate()

After much debugging of the subject bug, we've concluded that a
failure and an exception of OSError with EAGAIN from communicate()
indicates some monkey business. In the specific case that we're seeing

commit_message:
Prevent in-use flavors from being deleted

A flavor can be created or deleted at any time, no matter if
an instance references it or not. Since instances reference
the flavor by their 'flavor-id', which is not unique, you
can create, delete, and re-create the flavor using the same
flavor-id. This could cause issues with instance actions, e.g.
resize or rescue, because a re-created flavor with the same
flavor-id could have a different configuration. This patch
prevents a flavor from being deleted if it is in-use by an
instance.

rather than later to allow base classes to configure their internal
test tracking state. Failing to do so allows bugs like this one to
occur - when failure occurs early, the state required to gather

I've taken a fairly minimal approach here - I think it would be

It would help debugging considerably if a failure in execute()
generated a message (at a client specified logging level). Such a
message, generated by execute() would only occur if the user requested
it by specifying a parameter (log_errors), and execute() were to throw
an exception. As an example, this change would address the issue being
addressed in bug 1340124 for the Trove project only.

possible values of the log_errors parameter are 'all' or 'final'. The
default value of None implies no logging. If it is set to 'final',
stdout and stderr are logged on the final failure. If it is set to
'all', stdout and stderr are logged on every failure.

subject: Changed DSE to use eventlets rather than threads
commit_message:
Changed DSE to use eventlets rather than threads

Implements: blueprint dse

The current problem is that the DSE uses threads rather than
eventlets. This problem has two main issues that make it a
problem. First, the rest of Congress uses eventlets instead
of threads. The DSE should follow what the rest of Congress
uses and also use eventlets. The fix for that problem is to
make the DSE use eventlets rather than threads. The second
problem is that threads are not very scalable in Python and
there is a lack of performance because of Python's GIL, which
only allows one thread to execute at a time. That is not
useful in the situation of the DSE since we want multiple
lines of code to execute at a time because multiple services
are running at once. The fix for that problem is also to
switch the DSE to using eventlets rather than threads.

The fix for these two problems, which this change does, is to
change the DSE to use eventlets rather than threads. Instead of
the d6service class inheriting from threading.Thread, it now
inherits from eventlet.greenthread.GreenThread, which makes d6service
now an eventlet rather than a thread. This will fix scalability
issues as I mentioned above, and also make the DSE use eventlets
like the rest of Congress does.

Changed the implementation so that the spawning of the green
threads is hidden from the user and they can initialize a
service by just using: Service() instead of having to use
deepsix.SpawnService(Service).

subject: Storage Policy defined constraints middleware
commit_message:
Storage Policy defined constraints middleware

Adding a constraints middleware that allows different
constraints rules per storage policy.

Currently, Swift allows only one set of object naming
and metadata rules per cluster. As new storage policies
are implemented, it is possible that different storage
back-ends have different set of rules on how objects
should be created for that specific storage system.

This patch attempts to refactor some of the default
object validation in PUT requests, so that the validation
happens early enough to quickly respond with errors, but
also adds the ability to new middlewares to define
their own constraints for a specific storage policy.

A mem_constraints middleware was added to serve as an
example where objects stored on an object mem_server
would have more strict naming rules (e.g., name length
max is 128).

A real-world example of where this constraints middleware
is necessary can be found on the SwiftOnFile project.
SwiftOnFile has different rules as objects name are mapped
to a POSIX filesystem directory structure.
Example: no names with double slashes or ending with
slashes are allowed.
SwiftOnFile constraints middleware: http://goo.gl/a96Icc

Change-Id: I46361969979c7ed9477f34cba9f74c13e89617d9

Exporting via cloned VMs leaves the exported disks and snapshots

subject: HP 3PAR: Allow retype when the old snapshot CPG (3PAR pool) is None
commit_message:
HP 3PAR: Allow retype when the old snapshot CPG (3PAR pool) is None

A common provisioning group (CPG) is a virtual pool of logical disks.
A volume is stored in a CPG. The volume's snapshots may be stored in
the same CPG or in a separate CPG. In 3PAR this is the "snapCPG".

Before the 3PAR driver supported "manage", the snapCPG was never None in
OpenStack because when we create volumes, we explicitly default snapCPG
to match the volume CPG unless otherwise specified. So, the original
retype pre-checks raised an exception if this unexpected case occurred
and a unit test was provided for that exception.

Now that we support manage_existing(), it should be a valid use case
to manage an existing volume created outside of OpenStack with a snapCPG
set to None. Unfortunately, when we applied volume-type settings to this
volume we would hit that old exception.

That exception has been removed. 

Removing it required the following changes:

1. When retype pre-checks validate the domain of the new snapCPG, it
   will not use the optional old snapCPG. Instead it will compare the
   new snapCPG domain with the old volume CPG domain. This satisfies
   the requirement that domains cannot be mixed and avoids the need
   to have an old snapCPG setting.

2. Remove the no longer used old_snap_cpg parameter and remove the
   code that raised an exception "if not old_snap_cpg".

3. Remove the unit test that was just to test that obsolete exception.

4. Adjust the exiting test_retype_across_snap_cpg_domains to
   verify that a snapCPG domain that does not match the volume
   CPG domain will still raise Invalid3PARDomain

Change-Id: Icd2c66898ef64f81116df102f5529a8da30c14d5
Closes-Bug: 1368927

subject: Add atomic action names tracking
commit_message:
Add atomic action names tracking

Here we change the format of the scenario results so that it now stores
the atomic actions data as a dict:

    Before:
        {
            "duration": ...,
            "error": ...,
            "atomic_actions": [
                {"action": "a1", "duration": 0.3},
                {"action": "a2", "duration": 0.1},
                {"action": "a1", "duration": 0.25}
            ],
            ...
        }

    After:
        {
            "duration": ...,
            "error": ...,
            "atomic_actions": {
                "a1": 0.3,
                "a1 (2)": 0.25,
                "a2": 0.1
            },
            ...
        }

We also solve 2 connected problems here:

1. The statistics table that shows up in the CLI after benchmarks complete now
   always has rows for all the atomic actions that were invoked in benchmark
   scenarios. Before this patch, this was not the case since occasionally the
   atomic actions data could not be written due to Exceptions.

2. We've removed lots of ugly code in benchmark/processing/plot.py, since now
   there is no need to make passes through the atomic actions data to collect
   their names.

This patch also:
* contains some removing of code duplicate between plot & CLI output generation;
* adds missing UTs for raw benchmark data processing;
* fixes a minor bug in histograms bins number calculation.

Change-Id: I17f563051bd1c2ec2fb47a385d4cc652895e1f9e

subject: Adds new functional test suite for API samples
commit_message:
Adds new functional test suite for API samples

The existing functional test suite in Nova (in nova/tests/integrated)
suffers from terrible performance due to it spinning up a Nova
environment containing an API WSGI service endpoint, service daemons
for nova-conductor, nova-compute, nova-consoleauth, and running database
migrations for each test method of every test case class in the
test_api_samples.py test file.

All most of the api samples tests do is issue a simple HTTP request
against the API WSGI service endpoint and compare the results it gets
back to a stored api sample document in doc/api_samples/. It is not a
particularly CPU or memory-intensive test, but due to the framework
creating and recreating the Nova environment over and over, typical
runtimes of the nova/tests/integrated/test_api_samples.py tests can take
more than 5 minutes.

This patch adds a new functional test suite for running these kinds of
tests. It sets up a single Nova environment, loads a database and
fixtures, runs the tests, and then tears down the Nova environment.

This patch just adds tests for flavors and versions, in order to keep
the patch size manageable. The tests themselves have not actually
changed, and the new base test class for the functional tests shares 90%
of the code in the existing nova/tests/integrated/api_sample_test_base
file except the Nova environment is not created and recreated in setUp()
and tearDown() each time a test method is run.

The result is that the tests run in a fraction of the time that the
existing integrated tests run.

Change-Id: Ic5d186e33a3f423a38beb64b485eb7f6467ced29

subject: Non-EUI64 fixed IPs should be rejected for IPv6 SLAAC
commit_message:
Non-EUI64 fixed IPs should be rejected for IPv6 SLAAC

When a port is created on a subnet that is configured for IPv6 SLAAC,
that port's IP address will be automatically generated (to a
pre-determined value, based on the subnet's IPv6 prefix and the port's
MAC address) using the EUI64 address algorithm. Therefore, any port
create request that includes a fixed IPv6 address that does not match
the expected IPv6 EUI64 address should be rejected.

This change adds a check for any fixed IP addresses that do not match
the expected automatically-generated addresses for port creation on
an IPv6 SLAAC subnet.

This change also removes a check for duplicate address assignment on
IPv6 SLAAC subnets. Duplicate address assignments on IPv6 SLAAC should
be prevented by the following:
- IPv6 prefixes are confirmed to be unique when the subnet is created.
- MAC addresses are confirmed to be unique when a port is created.
- This new change will only allow unique EUI64 addresses (based on
  unique prefix and unique MAC address) to get assigned to a port
  on an IPv6 SLAAC subnet.
(I tried leaving in the existing check for duplicate addresses on
IPv6 SLAAC subnets, but was at a loss as to how to modify the existing
associated unit test to force duplicate addresses, because of the
considerations listed above.)

Closes-Bug: #1369767

subject: Remove second get call to list/show volumes
commit_message:
Remove second get call to list/show volumes

Recently it was observed that with large numbers of volumes
that things like "cinder list" could take extremely long to
return.

For example, running cinder list on a system with 1000 volumes took
greater than 30 seconds to return.  It turns out that the cause of
this is the addition of visible admin_metadata.

There's two problems with this:
1. The original patch probably shouldn't have gone in
   data is either admin data or it's not, selectively picking
   pieces of admin data out to provide to the user just creates
   complications and introduces confusion.
2. The REAL issue here is that since the standar gets are made
   with the standard user context, the add_visible_admin_metadata
   would go through and do an elevated context get on every single
   volume individually.  This is what caused the horrible performance
   issue on cinder list with large numbers of volumes.

Running as admin, or removing the second call drops this down to about 3
seconds for the same 1000 volume list.

This patch removes the secondary admin context get_call.  Instead where
we expect to do display the visible admin_meta, we pass in a flag
requesting that the volume object we're getting has the appropriate
metadata.  This way we can elevate the context if needed and avoid
iterating through the gets again.

This patch also cleans up the get_visible_admin_meta methods, and
consolidates both V1 and V2 to use the utils method.

Closes-Bug: 1317606
